description: From Middle French naumachie and its source, Latin naumachia.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A place built to stage a mock sea-battle, or the show performed therein. [17th c.]
examples: Lacedæmonians held their public banquets […], plays, naumachies, places for sea-fights, theatres, amphitheatres able to contain 70,000 men, wherein they had several delightsome shows to exhilarate the people […].
